review_title: VP in IT in Derivatives IT at Credit Suisse
pros: Excellent company that focusing on deliverying the best internally from within IT to gain the best results to the street.  The ability grow and have mobility are very good, and as is the compensation.
cons: Hours can be long, but then again hours are long in all investment banks.  The constant offshoring is something to watch out for.

pros: There was constant feedback from Seniors and Supervisor. HR was also very professional in how they conducted the whole attachment program. They went out of their way to make sure you fit in and felt comfortable.
cons: Roles within my department were very well defined and structured so you may not learn much after a short period of time.

review_title: Banking hours, but not a generous paycheck
pros: You get to work a lot, good experience. It still has a good name, compared to the other non-US bulge brackets.
cons: I work a lot, but in all fairness I am underpaid compared to peers on the street. There is constantly fear of an undersized bonus, and everyone on my team is constantly talking about leaving, which is not conducive to a good work environment. The name will still pale compared to the top US bulge brackets.

pros:
What I like the most is multi-cultural environment. We run project using SCRUM methodology. That improves our progress visibility to the project owner who is thousands miles away.
Last but not least people are awesome, energized and well organized.
cons: Internal policies and procedures slow down our work big time sometimes. Another frustrating thing is completely chaotic recruitment process causing candidates to wait for feedback for months.

review_title: Wish the good old days were back
job_title: IT Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Credit Suisse uses a strong technology stack
cons:
Job security is low, due to sustained losses
Firm  is trying to shore up expenses, so locking down many systems, making it very difficult to get your job done in technology. Also, skills are not reusable due to requirement to use custom in-house systems.

job_title: Quantitative Associate in New York, NY
pros: Good work/life balance by Wall Street standards.  Culture is reasonable and people are reasonably friendly.  Okay compensation.
cons: Extremely bureaucratic and inflexible, especially anything involving Information Technology.  Management usually has only myopic goals, since management at all but the very highest levels gets cycled through very quickly (while I was there MDs typically lasted ~2 years before being fired).  Unfortunately, when an MD is let go, typically almost everyone underneath that MD is kicked out as well.

pros: Large Investment Banking employer in a great location in NYC. Lots of very smart, talent people. Great development program that brought in ambitious analysts.
cons: The Operations Department had numerous leadership changes, outsourcing and layoffs which greatly diminished employee morale. Cost cutting should focus on continuous process improvement instead of mass movement of people.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good culture, very collegial, seems that there is emphasis on growing talent from within and internally promoting promising junior staff.
cons: Long hours like very other investment banking job, could have more employee appreciation events and free access to the pantry instead of having to pay for everything.

review_title: Great place to start your career
job_title: Cash Equity Sales Senior Associate in London, England
pros: Very professional training with high quality research product. Not as aggressive as American banks. Perfect place to start your career, lots of smart people around to learn from. Good salary structure.
cons: Big group so the structure can be a bit rigid. Not as meritocratic as initially thought. Difficult to move up the structure. Lack of transparency for bonuses.

pros: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush. Great guaranteed salary, so if you like that sort of thing, it's a great place to work. If there's any upside, they're pretty good about giving you some participation in it (but there rarely is).
cons: It's a meritocracy for the most part (which is good), but you're either in the club or you're not. If you're not, it really really doesn't matter how good you are (which isn't good).

pros: Some great people and a generally positive and encouraging culture where internal mobility is common.  Somewhat hierarchical in some areas but most good.
cons: Few critical functions are not well lead resulting in sub optimal decisions.  Pay middle if the road compared to peer group and little or no salary upside un main cities.

job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: All about finding your place with the right people. I was fortunate to have landed with a strong group and supportive team that provided me opportunities to grow. CS is improving and focusing on making junior experience better (in line with the rest of the industry).
cons: Hours and demands of client facing business can be challenging. Corporate culture that tends to be slow to react. Overall company trajectory is unclear and CS has been challenged in the public markets recently.

review_title: Good place to work but limited monetary incentives
pros:
1. Opportunity to work with talented people gives a good platform to learn and grow
2. Interaction with senior leaders gives you insight of firm goal and helps you plan your career
3. Work life balance is good as long as you meet your deadlines
cons:
1. Growth in terms of increase in pay is much below industry average . No attractive increments or bonus.
2. Indian management is not very open to growth discussion and internal mobility

review_title: Great if you're in the right department
pros: Ability to work from home, chances provided to those without degrees in finance or business
cons: Poor management, no assistance with escalated matters, long hours in which you make only half time of pay, poor leadership, no work/home life balance.

review_title: CS - a lot opportunities but too many org. changes
pros:
+ very  good professional (esp. bankers, traders)
+ excellent brand, esp. outside Switzerland
+ very extensive offering , esp. for corporate & institutional clients
+ dynamic with 'can do' mentality
cons:
- organization too complicated and never stable
- opening process too cumbersome

review_title: You'll get paid well, but they make you work for it
pros:
- Great starting salary as an analyst, which sets you up for your future career
- Interesting to work with high level executives
cons:
- Experience can be very dependent on the Associate / VP that you work for
- Extremely demanding hours; don't underestimate the impact this has on your life

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: They offered decent employee benefits.
cons: Moral was terrible within our department.  Salary was very low for a bank and bonus was laughable.

review_title: Credit Suisse has been a positive work environment
pros: It is a large public company with a strong balance sheet and the investment bank generates interesting work. It is a good place to learn the financial services industry with good resources.
cons: The hours, like any other bank are grueling and recognition from senior bankers is low for a junior banker. Career opportunities are bountiful afterwards, but more direct guidance from senior bankers would be helpful.

pros:
1. Brand value, CS is considered amongst top employers in Investment banking technology domain.
2. High salary.
3. Open culture.
4. Decent work life balance.
cons:
1. No regular transportation ( only after 10 pm though).
2. CTC is a lot bloated, so you need to negotiate on more in-hand amount.
3. Politics as in other companies.
4. Personally, I felt there was a less quality of work for people in Technology.

review_title: Great learning experience, in the best and worst sense.
pros: Great environment to learn software, customer service skills, and fast workflow overnight. Great benefits as well.
cons: Worst work ethic possible, employees are just worker bees building up the nest to support the queen. Used to be a great company but has grown more conservative and less people oriented, finding any place in the world to go the cheaper but not always better route. If they could hire robots to do the work, they would enforce it.

pros: Salaries are good, their benfits are terrific one of the best 401k matches out there.
cons: All politics, managers will copy & paste emails from direct reports only to send to their bosses to give the appearance that they're producing instead of reading everything about sports on the Internet.

pros: It is a very prestigious institution that holds itself to extremely high standards. Provides great opportunities and has a top team with human values. Located at an unbeatable place.
cons: IB hours are long, and no one cares that they're long, as it is a given in the industry. Still, this bank probably has among the most reasonable hours.

pros: Plenty of opportunities to grow.  Many projects available for individuals who are motivated and are looking to expand their Excel skills, as well as get a taste of business process improvement.
cons: For operations based roles, employee staffing model is to hire recent grads starting at a low salary.  Do not expect to be promoted even when putting in 50+ hours each week and implement process improvement to increase team capacity.

pros: Dynamic leadership, generally good ambience. CS provides a good environment with an in house gym, cafeteria, development program, and volunteering opportunities
cons: As a Swiss bank, it faces increasing challenges in doing business in the US. We see the bank cutting back its US business as a result.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Morrisville, NC
pros: able to work from home if with the right team.   Very international company.  Lots of diversity
cons: No pay increases and bonuses.    People have worked 8 years to get a move to  an AVP position and still no bump in pay.    The pay you start with is the pay you will end with.   People are leaving left and right.  They recently started laying people off

pros: This is a great company with a lot of opportunities for growth. They provide an atmosphere in which you can network and gain mentors rapidly to expedite your own growth within the company.
cons: Starting as a contractor is a great way to get your foot in the door. However, some departments have less ability to convert contractors to full time employees and the conversion process can be a lengthy one.

pros: Great pay and talented people. In addition, there is a good learning path and many opportunities to prove yourself. Great entry for anybody interested in wealth management.
cons: Conservative culture and little freedom. I experienced not as much support as I would have liked in terms of compliance and other areas of training. The culture could be more empowering.

pros: Very good corporate culture. I enjoyed working here and everyone was very laid-back. I definitely recommend to anyone interested in the supply chain field.
cons: I did not learn as much as I thought I would through the job. In the end, I have decided to leave so I can pursue a different job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great colleagues -- smart, creative, collegial. I had many opportunities to move around in different roles over the years and learned a lot. (Not sure that's still the case, in the current climate.) Excellent benefits, including maternity leave. Emphasis on "giving back"; plenty of volunteering opportunities. The 5-star rating reflects my overall experience at CS.
cons: The strategic reduction of US- and EMEA-based businesses means there are fewer opportunities in these regions. There have been many rounds of layoffs.

pros: Very collegial atmosphere despite that everyone is so busy, strong commitment to public service, excellent trainings (although some are repetitive).
cons: Recent transition period with mass lay-offs and cost-cutting, seems difficult to get promoted "on time", you better hit it off with your direct manager as there is no recourse in review process otherwise.

pros:
Business stakeholders are fabulous, clued in and know what needs to be done. 
Good compensation and career progression 
Needs greater thought and structure in hiring in support functions like HR
cons:
Unfortunately the HR team is totally disconnected from reality 
Complete lack of quality control in recent hires in HR, disengaged, lacking interest in doing what's right for the organization and its people 
Disappointing to see the poor quality of new entrants in HR, they don't deserve the title and salary they are getting!

pros: client facing role with great flexibility, responsible of obtaining new market shares and opportunities, creating relationships and building network, great career opportunity
cons: pressure on performance high, feels like every move is under pressure to deliver without acceptance for delay or underperformance., feels like everyday is a fight to keep job and position

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Learned a lot. Every team uses different technologies so plenty of things to learn. Can work from home if needed. All my managers there were easy to work with. Company paid for my masters degree.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy. Company rules are not flexible. Big team in India so group meetings (from NYC) can be difficult. It's a global company so many people/teams you work with are in a different state/country. Software development process is slow due to all the paperwork required.

review_title: Like with every corporation, depends on your team!
pros:
-Remote work
-International work environment
-Quite challenging
-Good benefits
-Good pay
-Ability to change role after a year
-Sabbatical after 5 years(yes, even in Poland)
I have a great line manager that does a very good job at keeping all the corporate activities away from me.
This may not always be the case.
cons:
I don't really see any cons, it depends on your team and role.
Maybe too many organizational meetings.
You need good english, not a con for me, but probably for some people.

pros: Coffee and fruits twice a week
cons: They give you no physical PC but a virtual protesis of a PC with single monitor. Every simple task at Credit Suisse is complicated as much as possible. "Poor quality" is their domain.  After working for few other major banks I must admit CS is most unorganized place.  It's like working place for most incompetent people in the world. If you consider applying for a job there think it through, wether you want to achieve anything or just waste time and get paid for it.

review_title: CS is a wonderful place to be...great culture, but work life balance is not great like any IB
job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros:
-Good culture, friendly people depending on which department
-Very conservative bank and seems to be a safer place to work on wall street
cons:
-Terrible work life balance
-Internal mobility is promoted on paper but in practice its quite tough to move around

review_title: Great learning experience but lower pay in SS compared to other investment banks.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: I enjoyed the learning experience of working in an area within Shared Services team. The culture of CS vs. other banks is much more European due to Swiss colleagues' ability to work abroad in NY office for one year
cons: Pay is lower than other firms. Shared services gets treated as back office even though some  parts of the team are client facing and integral to the bank's performance/reputation

review_title: Restructuring in progress -- overall focus on lowering costs
job_title: Equity Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: As a bulge bracket bank, there is good name recognition and reach of working at Credit Suisse.  Many of your colleagues are intelligent and ambitious.
cons: Opportunities with appropriate compensation for the work required are limited.  Given the bank's poor performance and the restructuring in place for the last ~2 years, most employees feel as though their job is always on the line.

review_title: Company goes through the hire/fire cycle more rapidly than other firms
pros: This is getting more difficult or a question as time goes on.  The company used to have pride and great benefits.  Both have been lost over the last few years.
cons: You are just a number in this company and even worse, completely expendable as newer and cheaper resource locations are identified.  Our teams have been reduced significantly (even entirely in certain cases) for cheaper offshore labor such as India.

review_title: Second Tier Bulge Bracket Investment Bank
pros:
- Generally good reputation among large cap clients
- Generally ethnically diverse
- Paid a reasonable salary and bonus
- Work/life balance varies greatly across groups, but is on par with the other investment banks
cons:
- Perennially considered a second tier investment bank
- Has a small balance sheet for a balance sheet bank and could strategically allocate more capital to the more strategic clients
- Facing recent regulatory related challenges
- NYC office is located in midtown south. Midtown proper is better

review_title: I was a senior voice engineer but had to dig deeply in networks and nearly became CCNP R&S
job_title: Senior Infrastructure Specialist in Moscow, Moskva
pros: the company tries to give everyone of equal opportunities, respects personal life, provides good social package
cons: I'd saw compensation level is lower then in the market in shared-services (IT in my case). huge disbalance, you can stay forever at work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Work life balance. Good benefits (401k, sponsorship for higher education, generous maternity and paternity, sabbatical...). Global exposure across entire banking spectrum provides extensive learning opportunities. Internal mobility to a limited extent.
cons: Complacency. Vertical growth very slow due to heavy management and flawed appraisal process. Pay below industry average. Low transparency and regard for good ideas due to few checks on management.

pros: The benefits are pretty great and the salary is respectable for the market. The raises were great and most groups are relatively played back (given the industry).
cons: The company seems to over hire to align with major initiatives and then lay off in mass as those initiatives unwind.

pros: Friendly work culture, good team to work with diverse employee back ground and recently more important has been given to Indian locations. Very good internal mobility options and company promotes employees to opt for internal mobility
cons: Before you join, make sure you get the salary right and promotion process is extremely slow and time taking

pros: There are opportunities to work with clever people. The working environment is on average relaxed. Provides good benefits and career opportunities through internal mobility.
cons: There is lack of meritocracy. Managers are not consistently good. There is significant aversion to change. Although there are lots of good people at AVP/VP level the quality of Directors/MDs is not as good.

job_title: Sales Associate in New York, NY
pros: Madison square park is a nice area of the city to work in. The cafeteria wasn't totally terrible. The entrance to the building was nice. The people I worked directly with were agreeable.
cons: It took them two weeks just to get my computer setup. The orientation day was one of the most boring and tedious things I've ever encountered. Most of the senior opps people who knew how to get things done were fired and everything took FOREVER to get completed.

job_title: Vice President Product Control in New York, NY
pros: The colleagues are great. People are easy to deal with. If you build up goodwill over time, managers tend to be more flexible with working arrangements.
cons: There are often many ad hoc requests from senior management and regulators that can overwhelm your schedule and work/life balance. Regulatory compliance expenses are a drag on the firm's bottom line, which negatively impacts bonuses.

pros:
- competitive salary
- work life balance
- flexible working time
- nice benefits
- private medical care
- pension plan
cons:
- decision making process outside Business Development Centers
- it is impossible that somebody in Poland could be team head if teams are spread between UK and Poland, even if there are more people working in Poland, there are more competencies etc.

pros: Generally surrounded with nice people, fairly relaxed in comparison to other banks, competitive/decent salaries. Training encouraged and keeping up with technology trends.
cons:
- General atmosphere and moral gone down due to recent massive cuts.
- Political environment.
- Work became less interesting.

review_title: Good place to work but it’s “The Swiss Civil Service”
pros:
Good people to work with
Pay reasonable for the financial services industry 
Very generous pension contributions
cons:
Bureaucracy. Typical many investment banks 
Technology and methods about 10 years behind 
IT services outsourced to Poland and India

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros: sick days, maternity leave, paternal leave ,flexible work hrs
cons: promotion process is not properly defined, getting to next level takes years and very disappointing as there is no unique process, it all depends on the manager

review_title: A goto place for a lot but not that great. watch out
pros: Quite good benefits and new things to learn. Endless things to learn from. If you are in with right folks ofcourse.
cons: Chaotic environment and poor quality of work culture. Caused because of the influx of temporary employees from other international locations

review_title: Credit Suisse seems like a great place to work, but I was stuck in a bad team.
job_title: Credit Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Good pay, good benefits.
Intelligent, sharp co-workers.
Better than average work/life balance, in my experience.
Great if you like your immediate surroundings/supervisor.
cons:
Still very corporate.
Can be frustrating if you are in a group where the culture is different than your own.

pros: People are very nice, good work-life balance.
cons: Not as challenging as other IB's, responsibilities are very divided among multiple groups rather than grouped under one umbrella to offer employees a broader perspective on job functions.  You can become to silo'ed into one area it seems.

pros: Good compensation, decent people to work with
cons: Lack of direction from management, poor work life balance -- constantly need to be checking emails and overworked at times and receiving calls at odd hours of the day to provide support, not many chances to advance your career

review_title: Supportive, friendly, team environment where everyone feels open to making their contribution
pros:
- Great compensation package, not just salary but also other flexible benefits, including exclusive access to CS gym if you work in London Canary Wharf
- People are welcoming and friendly, and you are supported in making a contribution as well as if you want to move around within the firm
cons: - Don't think there are any major cons here, could develop internal training courses a bit though

review_title: Good company to work for but currently a challenging environment
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: A very good company to work for. They have very strong sense of community and allow the employees to participate in many diverse philanthropic events.
cons: Currently a very challenging environment to work in. There is tremendous change happening at the moment as many business functions are being reduced or shipped overseas to lower cost locations.

review_title: Overall skills development and relationship building
pros: It provides excellent work life balance for personal development in the spare time. A good company to spend   atleast 2 years and pushing for personal growth/promotion.
cons: The year end compensation is not as high as expected from the industry. Also, it does not have any manual for learning for any new joiners for effective handover. With more specialisation in work, the work is becoming more systematic leaving little brain to be applied for analysis

pros: Good on the job training. Flexible work hours. Much upside potential. Healthy work-life balance with many sports facilities provided. Zurich is a treat.
cons: Rather rigid hierarchies.  Rely too heavily on monetary as opposed to other forms of incentives. Changing departments may be difficult. Upside potential may be only available within the strand of work pursued.

pros: Internal mobility is one of the great qualities of Credit-Suisse, as it really helps to grow as a person and professional.  The vacation, maternity / paternity, and honeymoon benefit packages are by far better than 99% of other employers.
cons: Workforce management - meaning between sites: New York - to Raleigh - to London - to etc; you may be a team of one and it is hard to find support and leadership in the current global setup.

job_title: Senior Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Solid ultra high net worth customer base globally, after all this is a Swiss bank
cons: Mgmt eats their words.  Middle managers have no power to give promotions or bonuses as they see fit.  They burn people out and replace after people quit.

review_title: Cool Team Spirit but IT & Top Management a disaster
pros:
Demanding but very exciting Job.
High degree of freedom to perform my Job
Very strong support from my line-manager
Team spirit was amazing
cons:
IT is a  absolute disaster
Legal Compliance is all over the place. That I did not had to ask for LCD approval to go to the toilet is everything.
Could not identify with top management.
Constant fear of more cost cuts

pros: Cosmopolitan workforce, opportunities for secondment (role dependent) and, if you are fortunate enough to be in a collaborative team, collegiate environment.
cons: The concept of rising stars is a farce and mainly consists of charlatans  who use machiavellian tactics in order to rise above the rest with a management infrastructure that is out of touch with employees who truly deserve acknowledgement.

pros: Friendly and flexible culture at the organization is the only motivating element
cons:
Salary is not in line with the skill sets of the employees and the criticality if the work undertaken . It is not at par with the colleagues having lower or equal level of experience and skillsets. 
The discussions involving growth of employees career or the roadmap for the immediate future is totally missing . Wide communication gap across all the levels.

review_title: Based on who you know not what you know
pros: Overall work life balance is good.
cons:
Definitely an "Old Boy Network" to move ahead.  Skills are not required to be a manager but how you manage your relationships.
They claim to be all about Internal Mobility but managers will block good people from moving to new positions.

pros: very nice and pleasant to work for. office are excellent, only Goldman Sachs has better offices in the tower. Very pleasant people.
cons: There is a always a lot of work (i guess that can also be a good thing), and the pressure is quite high. but in the same time everyone at CS is very nice!!

review_title: "Great for people who have long term career aspirations" Team Leader, Global Information Security
pros: The global banking environment, emphasis on technical / behavioural trainings, great work life balance. HR is very strong and not the puppet of management.
cons: Internal politics, upper management listens to their delegates...they are not really interested to talk to their employees, even if they do... its just for formality.

pros: Great pay, great experience, you learn a lot and your technical skills ramp up quickly - lots of modeling practice and exposure to deals and clients
cons: Very Long hours, very inefficient, the nature of the job does not allow for much work life balance, very bureaucratic,

pros: Nice environment to work in and you have a work/life balance.
cons: Compensation especially when promoted is well below market.  New CEO's vision, unwind of businesses and restructuring leave many employees dissatisfied and leaving CS.

review_title: Used to be great but times have changed
job_title: Human Resources Manager in London, England
pros:
The people all work very hard and really care about the company.
Hard to get promoted but done very fairly.
Good at encouraging internal mobility.
cons:
Priorities have changed significantly since the new management came in and people are no longer the priority.
Salaries are low in the market.
Cost savings initiatives are beginning to have an impact on the well being of staff.

pros: Definitely a good company to start your professional career with. Good trainings, and benefits.
cons: After 2 years the responsibilities become repetative and there is no much room for development. Young and inexperienced people are appointed as managers and given their lack of experience they are not able to properly manage a team.

pros:
Work-life balance
Friendly, cooperative co-workers, good culture and values
Excellent office location
cons:
Company not doing great, CEO's strategy really doubtful. Cost cutting is actually conservative. MD's rather not aligned with Management Board strategy. 
Bulky management structure, low amount of "do'ers"
Lack of innovation, bottom-up initiatives are chance-less
People in management positions are operationally excellent, but often bad people managers. 
Low bonuses
Little opportunities for training (or funding)
Average facilities, low cost open spaces, bad cleaning, bad IT-tools/software, BYOD policy, etc.

review_title: An entrepreneurial culture with lean teams and access to management
pros: APAC Division - quicker decisions being made and more responsive to clients. Management listens to ideas and actions the best - creating Alpha.
cons: On-going restructuring and cost constraints. Lack of female role models and overall diversity at the bank - though looking at strategies to improve on this.

pros: The company is not that competitive and they have mentorship program and if you are fortunate your mentor can be a very important point of contact.
cons: The moral was really low at times especially with the stock market crashing and people being hopeless. However this was common to all banks and not just Credit Suisse.

review_title: There are a lot of politics.
pros: As with any investment banking job the pay is good so that keeps me around.  The benefits package is also very generous.
cons: It is very political at CS.  It is hard to get promoted and it is more about who you know than what you do,

review_title: Good history, but in decline as best are rapidly leaving
pros: Still has some good 'old school' high calibre people, still very strong/top tier in specific areas of IBD and capital markets. Still offers good exit opps.
cons: Best people are rapidly leaving the firm, no longer as good as it was in a number of areas, is falling down the ranks. Swiss regulatory issues don't help either.

review_title: Do not expect a long career at this company
job_title: Accounting and Finance in New York, NY
pros: Convenient location with an accommodating work schedule.
cons: To much focus on cost efficiency leading too many layoffs. Do not expect a long term career at this company. They are constantly reorganizing with an emphasis on deploying jobs to low cost locations.  Bonuses are much lower than other banks of its caliber.  Their main driver is to stay competitive with the least headcount.

pros: Smart and generally good people, good work life balance
cons: The general vibe is a little less intensive or dynamic than say Goldman which is a bad thing in terms of the bank's trajectory toward the top but a good thing for those who don't want their soul 100% owned.

pros:
Company cares about the employee, great culture.
Fairly flexible and supportive of an environment that provides growth.
cons:
Your happiness depends a lot on the type of manager you get.
Often due to poor planning you are left cleaning up someone else's mess.

pros: Great benefits, pay above average for my profession, able to go home on time nearly every day (rarely does work pile up), benefits for LGBT employees & their partners / spouses, great sizable year-end bonus
cons: Rarely thanked, institutionalized "class system"

pros: Better focus from business in terms of actual delivery, you get to learn a fair bit if you are in the right group & some groups really use cutting edge technologies, strong tendency to have shared code base and working on internal open source which very few banks do.
cons: A lot of groups in India are remote controlled via London, Hong Kong or Singapore, and the managers are political so be careful.

review_title: Good employer, but some cost cutting negatives
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Good people and department management is great.
cons: Considerable cost cutting measures are being implemented and these are negatively effecting the quality of life at Credit Suisse. Frequent tendency to add responsibilities to employees when others depart without any increase in pay or job title.

pros: Benefits are good.  Some groups have working from home flexibility.  Moderate mobility opportunities.  Work is challenging.
cons: Feels like you work for the little sister of the main site in NY and Managers make it worse.  Young work crowd makes it feel like you are in high school.  Culture so-so.

pros: I started working at CS after college because they have a great program for recent graduates. During the program they invest a lot of resources into training for you.
cons: Sometimes you're role can be very specific and monotonous at times. It's easy to take long lunches and leave early if you want.

pros: Wonderful culture.  Working in the US for an European bank affords a host of benefits (vacation, insurance, child care etc.) that most U.S. based equivalents do not have.
cons: Base salaries can be a bit low, and they move our floors more often than anyone would like.  But other than that, no major complaints.

pros: Smart people, lots of communication especially among team members, and good work environment. It's a good company to work for and can lead to additional opportunities.
cons: Work hours could be highly variable at times. Deadlines were created even when due dates weren't until much later. Pay could be better.

review_title: Great place for junior to mid-level
pros: - Very diversified organisation with a number of small teams - all the benefits (and drawbacks) of working in a big corporation and being a part of a smaller team
cons:
- Beyond mid-level promotion becomes difficult and political
- Unclear strategy - deploy capital in lending, trading, private banking or advisory

job_title: Market Risk Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits and work life balance. CS has one of the best child leave policies in the country. The primary care giver can get 5 months of paid time off. 401k is very good. There is no matching, the company just pays into your 401k regardless of how much you contribute (up to $10k a year depending on your salary)
cons: Morale very low with constant management and organizational changes.

review_title: Credit Suisse: great for starting a career in financial industry
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY

review_title: Most IT workers in U.S offices are foreigners or recent college hires.
pros:
It is a job (when most U.S. IT jobs have been outsourced to foreigners).
Schedule flexibility (very limited).
Internal training (very limited).
Business casual dress code (jeans allowed).
Opportunity for new hires to gain broad professional experience.
cons:
Managers discourage employee engagement in internal training opportunities but encourage participation in goofy activities to make their team look active in company community. 

It is a very punitive environment; team has been told that if anyone misses reporting their status on time, forgets to close a request for change (RFC) on time, etc., even just one time, their rating is automatically reduced to a B. Getting a B status would prevent the team members from qualifying for internal mobility and could impact their salary and bonus, if there is one. 

IT employees have to listen to bastardized English all day because very few IT workers speak fluent English, and workers are expected to understand the message that is relayed even if the wrong message is mistakenly delivered. Employees receive conflicting messages regarding the assignment expectations and are expected to meet the different expectations at the last minute.

Managers from India, and even workers from India, seem to aggressively push for work to be sent off-shore or to bring more off-shore employees to the US. They look for excuses to send the work off-shore. They try to facilitate sending work off-shore too, but do not assist the U.S. workers in the same way.

It is definitely a foreign work environment, not an American work environment. It is like entering India when you arrive on the IT floors. 

The schedule flexibility is minimal and managers ding you if you exceed their undocumented and unspoken quota, even if they approve it (late arrival due to doctor appointment or work from home). 

There is a significant communication problem in IT due to the language and cultural barriers.

The application-level onboarding is terrible. 

The communication gap and cultural gap create much unnecessary frustration for employees, not to mention the loss of information critical to the success of projects, and draining the morale.

Foreigners promote foreigners like in a good old boys type of network, excluding U.S. citizens. 
They promote the foreigners at the expense of the U.S. citizens. When work is going well for a U.S citizen, they will yank it from them and send it off-shore. When the foreign manager is in a jam due to being behind on something way overdue, they will assign it to a U.S. citizen. They do very little to help the U.S. citizen learn applications even when other workers are familiar with it, but expect the U.S. citizen to learn and document the applications to make it "easy" to bring the off-shore workers up to speed, to send the work off-shore when there are unemployed U.S. citizens who could do the work right here.
